author: R Srikanth
text:
For the past one week, hawkers in and around T. Nagar bus terminus have been finding it difficult to conduct their business as the police and the officials of Metropolitan Transport Corporation (MTC) have been trying to get them to move out.

A. Satish, joint secretary, Democratic Trade Union Centre, said that during the last one week, the local police officials, based on complaints from MTC officials at the T. Nagar bus terminus, had been detaining and fining the hawkers.

Citing the Madras High Court judgement dated September 30, 2015, M. Shreela, an activist from Virugambakkam, said the police and MTC officials had to stop the harassment of the hawkers. She said, “The High Court judgement states: ‘All the existing street vendors/hawkers operating across the country shall be allowed to operate till the exercise of registration and creation of vending/hawking zones is completed in terms of the 2009 hawking policy.’”

MTC officials said that these hawkers — who were mostly engaged in selling fruits, vegetables and small household articles — were causing a hindrance to the movement of commuters and also hampering the operation of bus services.

A senior official of MTC said that based on complaints from MTC officials, the police were taking steps against the hawkers, which includes slapping fines on them.
title: Hawkers complain of harassment
